text:
I'm Steve Bowsher,
not Steve Blank,

and I'm the CEO of In-Q-Tel. I've been at In-Q-Tel
for 18 years. If you're not familiar
with In-Q-Tel,

In-Q-Tel is an independent,
not for profit, a 501(c)(3) that invests on
behalf of the US intelligence

community in emerging technology
startup companies with the goal of facilitating the piloting and
adoption of those technologies

by the agencies
that we work with. We were founded by CIA,
actually, 25 years ago.

They created us. But today, we now work
with the entire IC-- CIA, NSA, FBI, DIA, NGA, NRO,
CBP, TSA, CISA, Cybersecurity

and Infrastructure
Security Agency. So they have security
twice in their name. And then some
components of the DOD.

So we work with US Navy,
we work with US CENTCOM, and we work with
the US Space Force.

We also work with the Australian
and the British government. So we have 15 different
partnership relationships.

We've been investing in
this space for a long time. We're excited to see
so much interest in it. 10 years ago, 15
years ago, there

wasn't this much interest
in it, but it's really matured as an industry and as a
segment of the venture capital

industry. And we think that's
great for the country and great for
entrepreneurs, like AJ.

So is that good
enough for you, Steve? All right. AJ, we'll have you sit. I'll sit here.

I'll grab my list of questions
here and we'll get started. So, AJ, before we
start anything else,

I love a good origin story. So tell me where
you grew up, how you got to where you were
ready to start Hermeus.
All right. Very good. So AJ Piplica. I was born in New York.

Contrary to what
most people think, there's a big joke going around
that I was born in Canada. It's not.

But, yeah, New York right
outside of the city, Westchester County. I lived there until
I was about six and then moved down to
Florida, down to Tampa.

So I grew up there. And then came to Georgia Tech
in Atlanta in 2005 for undergrad

there. So studied aerospace
engineering. How I picked that?

I really always
liked things that fly and I like to build things. I didn't really know what
aerospace engineering was.

I thought aeronautical
engineering had a cooler name. It was more real. But decided to go to a school
that was pretty well-ranked.

And I learned very, very
quickly what it was. I think my first introduction
to aerospace engineering class,

first day, the professor
comes in and asks, OK, everybody, write down
your three favorite airplanes. And I'm like, Delta.

This is how much not of a
cool aerospace engineer I was. So I learned pretty quickly,
got my first internship

working out at NASA Johnson
Space Center in Houston, Texas. And that was a pretty
interesting opportunity.

It was a co-op, so
I got to go back a couple times doing
different things originally. So I got to work on the--

it's called the wing
leading-edge impact detection system for the space shuttle. So after the Columbia
accident, they

instrumented the space
shuttle with a bunch of accelerometers to see
if it got hit by foam, or micrometeoroids,
or anything like that

to make sure that the astronauts
were safe coming back. So I worked that
for a little bit, and then I started to get
into the things that actually,

sent me down this path to
building a hypersonic aircraft company. And that came through my
second tour down at Johnson,

where I got to work in a
part of the center that focused on analysis
of lunar landers

coming back and
landing on the moon. They wanted to understand
where all the dust goes. Because if you want
to build a moon base,

you need solar panels. And they wanted
to how far away do we have to put the landing pad. So I got into what was called
Direct Simulation Monte Carlo

Analysis, basically,
computational fluid dynamics for non-continuum
or rarefied flows.

So basically, flows in a
vacuum, where molecules act more like billiard
balls than actual fluid.

So it started in the
analysis land there. And then the same
group there was working on a bunch of space
shuttle reentry, aero heating

analysis, and testing. And I got to dip
my feet in there. And that, I really,
really loved.

So I got hooked on
aerodynamics and space at the same time,
which was a mistake, because they didn't tell me that
it's just a vacuum up there.

So there's not much
for an aerodynamicist to do, other than rocket
engines or reentry.

And me liking
airplanes and wanting to get into those
kinds of things. I found the little niche that--

thank you. That bridged all of those things
along with what I really liked, which was hypersonics.

So flying very, very
fast in the atmosphere, greater than Mach five. So that made its way
into my work at Johnson

through space shuttle
reentry a good chunk of any space vehicle's
re-entry processes

in the hypersonic regime. I got to learn from some of
the foundational engineers in the area, which
was really cool,

and really got to learn
in the analysis land and going back and forth
between that job and school, and that job and school
over a couple of semesters,

wrapping up my undergrad,
really solidified this is what I want to work on. This is the cutting edge
of aerospace and aviation

that people really haven't
broken the frontier of in quite some time.

So after undergrad, I
went to grad school, had an opportunity either to
go back and continue co-oping

at Johnson or take
a new opportunity working at a conceptual
design company in Atlanta.

The origin story there
actually involves Bill Nye, the Science Guy. We'll get to that
later if we have time. But I decided to
try something new

and work for this
conceptual design company. And they had a need
for a particular skill

set that I had built in the
work that I was doing at NASA. And it worked out really well. So there, I got to work on
conceptual design for all sorts

of things, things I wasn't
particularly interested in, like Hall-effect thrusters,
and in-space propulsion,

and electrical power systems,
and things like that. But that helped me
learn conceptual design. But what I really, really
loved was the high speed,

air breathing stuff
that I got to work on. So both the rocket-based
things and in air breathers.

So reusable boosters
and hypersonic aircraft were the programs
that I got to work. And I got really lucky
because there was really

only one group in the entire
US Air Force, or almost the entire US government
at the time, that was working on hypersonics.

We basically killed all of
our hypersonics programs after the financial
crisis and sequestration. And there was one little group
at the air force research

laboratory at Wright-Patt
Air Force Base that was still working on this. And that's the group
that I happened to get to work for work for.

So I got to work on
early conceptual designs for the programs that, since
then, a little over 10 years ago

now, have now become
the hypersonic weapons programs that we have that
are pretty close to fielding.

So that was pretty neat to
see the early days of those. But even in undergrad,
I had an itch

to earn an entrepreneurial
experience. And what I got
wasn't quite that.

It was maybe the
best of both worlds. But I had an opportunity to take
an entrepreneurial experience. So not step out on my own and
try to start a company from

the very beginning, but within
this 20-person small business that was family-owned, basically
start up and run a subsidiary.

And the ownership
there had spent a lot of time understanding the
small satellite launch world. I'm sure everybody
here at Stanford

has paid a lot of
attention to that. So much money has
been raised off the SpaceWorks' small
satellite launch forecast
over the past decade. It's wild. But yeah, so we saw this-- --at least three or four.

I imagine so, yeah. Yeah, Planet was certainly
at the beginning of that.

But so I guess get
started in that, and was basically handed a
company and said, it's just you.

You don't have any money. We'll pay your salary. Go see what you can do. So it took a year building
that and refocus, reorganize

the company, and the plan
that we want to take down, and pivoted a little bit away
from small satellite launch

and focusing on the first
step in the technical roadmap toward that end, which was
high speed flight test.

So this is in 2013. The company is called
Generation Orbit.

And, yeah, basically
built it up. Won a handful of small
government contracts.

And over the next five years,
turned those into about a 15 to $20 million
development program

for an air launched
liquid rocket that got an x-plane designation as
X68, which is pretty sweet.

So we built a team, again,
all bootstrapped, no venture capital, built a team of
a little under 20 people.

And that really
started in about 2015. So about three years
building that technology.

Took it through a bunch of
ground testing and flight testing. And then got to the point
where, really, for this company

to be successful, it was
clear to me, as the leader, we needed additional capital. We were not going
to be able to move

not just equipment, and scaling,
and so forth, but the talent that we thought we
were going to need.

The family ownership didn't
want to go that route. And I don't blame them. You're like, hey, we've had
this company for 20 years.

Let's bet the farm
on these four kids. So I don't blame them at all. But this was now 2018.

We'd gotten through a
bunch of milestones, and we continued
to pay attention to what was going on in
the DOD hypersonics world.

And it was clear that
everybody was laser, laser focused on hypersonic weapons. And rightly so. I mean, that was the
technology in an area where

we were very far behind some
of our nation state competitors and the first natural
application of a very

difficult technology to a
real operational mission. But with that myopic lens that
I think the DOD was looking at,

nobody was really
looking at it like, OK, let's say we're successful
at catching up or getting

on par with our adversaries
here, what's next? And for us, that was
hypersonic aircraft.

That was wildly clear, take
reusability and bring it to hypersonic systems
for the military.

And then as we continue
to mull around this idea, it also became clear like, OK,
reusable hypersonic aircraft

are fundamentally a
dual use technology. If you can take
off in one place,

fly really fast and
land somewhere else, what you do in between, whether
you take pictures, shoot missiles, drop bombs, whatever,
you can also carry things

with you from
point A to point B. And that opens up a pretty
wild commercial opportunity

in the endgame, which
is orders of magnitude larger than the
national security applications of the technology.

But it was also
clear we're not just going to go raise
billions of dollars to go build a commercial
passenger aircraft.

So we had seen a bunch of money
going into this high speed mobility space, but
together with the experience

that myself and my
co-founders had, who all came from
SpaceX and Blue Origin, we worked together
for a couple of years, but the military applications
and private capital coming in,

there was no defense tech
investing space at the time. But we had a hunch
that there was

an appetite for this
type of technology and these types of capabilities
for our customer set. And that's really the
core thing that matters.

If your customers are there and
they want what you're building, money will come. So that was the origin story
of us founding Hermeus.

And I'm going to
pause you right there. Since I love a
good origin story, I also want to ask
the audience here. So how many of you
guys are undergrads?

Raise your hands. All right. How many of you
are grad students? And how many of you are
members of the community,

but neither undergrads
nor grad students? All right. Awesome. I'd love to have a sense
of who we're talking to.

Great origin story. I want to follow up on that. But there are two
things that you

mentioned in that first answer
that I want to follow up on. Why did they kill hypersonics?

Oh, well I mean, they
killed a lot of things during sequestration. Yeah. So hypersonics has been
like, murdered multiple times

over history. I think the first time
was probably around,

the space shuttle days. So we built the x-15. It was an experimental rocket
plane that was reusable.

It flew 199 times. It would have flown 200 if it
hadn't snowed in the desert.

That's a true story. And so we had hypersonic
reusable systems in the 1950s

and 1960s. And the data that was gathered
through operating that vehicle-- I won't call it an airplane. We can argue about that later.

But that created the data set
that was needed to go develop

and design the space shuttle. But we went the rocket route. So the flying fast
in the atmosphere

really dove off a
little bit after that. And then it was resurrected in
the 1980s with a program called

the National Aerospace Plane. So this was a single-staged
to orbit, pie in the sky

dream of a system that
was too good to be true, some people said. It turns out, it was
indeed too good to be true.

So we had poured the nation's
brain trust into this vehicle.

I think we were spending
$10 billion a year on this. We had 10,000 people working on
this thing that was never going

to work. And that eventually
got canceled. And that created a really
bad taste in people's mouths

around the hypersonic
technology. It was always something that
was like, 10 years in the future and always will be, so why
should we invest in it?

And then we had a little bit
of a renaissance around it from the science community. So NASA had a program
called the X-43,

which was the first hydrogen
powered scramjet vehicle. So it's supersonic
combustion ramjet, so air

breathing really high speed. That was flown in
the early 2000. I think they flew it
two or three times.

And then the air force
had another program called the X-51, which was
the first long-duration cruise

scramjet vehicle
that was ever built that flew for
about five minutes.

You laugh, but that's a
huge, huge achievement

in the hypersonics world. So, of course, we had the
SR-71 Blackbird and everything in the back in the day.

But that renaissance
in hypersonics was killed by sequestration.

There was just not
enough money to do the things we had to do with
the department of defense.

And this was, of
course, in the midst of the global war on terror. And hypersonics just was
on the chopping block.
So you saw it in the DOD. You saw it in NASA. Really, everywhere.

And then the next resurrection
that came back was-- So one of the things that we
did do in the X-43, X-51 days,

we published
everything, which means we did the homework for
all of our adversaries

around the world. And they, for
fortunate for them, didn't have sequestration
to deal with. So they spent that seven
or eight-year period,

not just sitting around
twiddling their thumbs, but building and flying
hypersonic systems. So that is how we got behind
in the technology space.

And now we have China with
missiles that can really hold our carrier
strike groups at risk,

which is an unacceptable
risk posture for the country. And that's the thing
that has now rekindled

interest in hypersonic weapons. These are, of course, weapons
that fly fast in the atmosphere, and not for the
same mission set.

We have different mission sets
with our concepts of operations, but that's been
this ebb and flow

of hypersonics over the years. It's like the 17-year itch. Look, that's a
great explanation. I appreciate you sharing
it with the class

because I think one
of the things you'll hear is you hear from
different folks over the course of this quarter is our DOD,
despite its large budget,

can't do everything. And it's making a
series of choices about where it's
spending its money, where

it's not spending its money. Sometimes those are
the correct choices. Sometimes those are
the incorrect choices.

And for whatever reason DOD
hasn't built this themselves or can't build them themselves,
let's go after that opportunity.

So I think it's a
really exciting time to be an entrepreneur
in this space. Because given the threat
challenge that we're

facing as a country,
the number of things we need versus the
amount of resources that we have the first one
exceeds the second one.

And that's always a great
market sign for an entrepreneur to go out and start something. If I could comment on that.

So the situation we're in is we
have a threat environment that is evolving on a, I
don't know, daily basis,

becoming more and more
difficult to deal with. I mean, you see what's going
on in Ukraine, and Israel,

and the Middle East, which
is all a precursor of vision into the future of what could
happen in the South China

Sea, which, of course,
is the thing that we all want to deter from happening.

And then you pair that with a
defense budget that isn't even keeping up with inflation,
plus, I don't know,

98, 99% of that
defense budget goes to a small number
of defense primes that have been around
for decades and decades

and really have no incentive to
deliver more for less, change.

Yeah, whatever you
want to call it. So the defense budget
isn't going to double. I'll tell you that right now.

And if we're going to
continue to deter conflict, then we have to solve
those problems differently.

And that's where the opportunity
space is for entrepreneurs. Absolutely. So, all right, let's get
back to the evolution

now that we've moved past
the origin story, Hermes. You guys are out there. First of all, how did you
find your co-founders?

There's three co-founders in
addition to yourself of Hermes. How did you find them? And then how did you think
about this transition point

from being an entrepreneur
to being an entrepreneur and raising outside capital? Yeah, so don't laugh.

LinkedIn. I'm notoriously good at
cold LinkedIn emails. But yeah, so I hired all three
of them at my previous company.

Two of them were just
actual cold LinkedIn. I've never met you before. I looked at your profile. I need a GNC engineer.

You're doing aerodynamics and
systems engineering stuff. I read his dissertation.

It's the only dissertation
I've ever read. But it was about very much this
high-speed flight test thing

that we were doing at
[INAUDIBLE] at the time. If you're working on a
dissertation, don't worry, at least two people
will read it.

Here's the trick. When you publish your
dissertation, it goes, it gets printed, it
gets put in the library, put a $20 bill in it, come
back five or 10 years later,

see if it's still there. Yeah, and then you know. But anyway. Yeah. And then my other
co-founder had applied.

He was at Blue
Origin at the time and wanted to move back east
to be closer to his family. So we worked together for three
years at Generation Orbit.

With a less than 20-person
team trying to fly a rocket off of a Gulf Stream airplane, you
tend to be down in the trenches

quite a bit together. So it's not like you're
the CEO of this company. You're sitting in
your high tower

making sure everything
happens and just playing with the chess pieces. No. You are in there and
turning wrenches,

bleeding in the trenches,
making calls left and right. And that really builds a very
strong bond amongst teammates.

And that, I think, was one
of the most important things for us starting the
company when we did.

I mean, we were
mostly in our 30s. So three of us are married,
one of us is single,

and one had three kids. So not a normal
setup, necessarily, for quitting your relatively
good paying jobs and starting

an airplane company. But what we did have along-- so we had a couple
of things here.

So we had conviction
in the mission, what we were trying to do, the outcome if we were successful
being significantly large,

and we had trust in each other. And I think that was the core
set of things that really allowed us to take this risk.

We also time boxed everything. So we were like, we
think this will work. We're pretty sure this is going
to work, but it might not.

So let's set expectations
with our family. So we're like, all right,
we're going to take six months and see if we can prove
our thesis correct, which

is, the thesis at the time was
basically like, you can raise money against this
idea with a PowerPoint,

because we didn't
have any money. I think we started the
company with $12,000. And we did all sorts
of fun little things.

We did a bunch of CFD
that we got paid for. That paid for some flights to
San Francisco for fundraising.

We got invited to YC interviews. We didn't get in, which was
fun, but it was a free trip to San Francisco for
other investor meetings.

Did YC say why they
didn't take you? Oh, yeah-- I will say this, by the way.

Investors will
tell you all sorts of reasons why they say no. It's rarely the truthful reason. Yeah, so these are actually
some hilarious ones.

We're worried about how much
fire it's going to make. We're worried about you giving
the passengers concussions.

I'm like, guys. Oh, and then there was another
guy who was like, yeah, I'll be fine with my G650. It's cool.
OK. It's cool. All right, dude. I mean. So that was fun. I think it's a complex business.

And to be able to
convey it to people in three minutes is
really difficult. And we were by no means
good enough at it.

We have four engineers trying to
communicate with other humans. We were lucky. We just didn't stare at
our shoes the whole time.

But, yeah, so it
didn't get in there. But, I mean, Sam Altman wrote
a pretty sizable check later,

so I'll take that as a win. And so then you raised
your first round? Yeah, yeah. So raised our first round.

So we gave ourselves six months. It took us literally every hour
of every day of every month of those six months to do it. I was on stage at
a pitch competition

when the money came in. We ended up losing the pitch
competition, which is hilarious. But the firm invested
anyway, so it was all good,

at a higher valuation. But yeah, so Khosla Ventures
was our first money in.

I got to know a couple
of the Skybox founders, so another batch
of Stanford grads,

in this six-month process of
learning how to spell "VC" and how this all worked.

And our path was actually
quite similar to theirs. KV was the first money
into them as well.

They were the first mover in
this small satellite market, venture backed. They were the first exit.

So we learned a lot from Dan
Berkenstock, and John Fenwick, and CY. I think Dan talked to
this class last year.

Is that right? Yeah. So a great guy. He's still floating around here. He came back. He dropped out of his PhD
program to start Skybox.

And once they sold
it to Google, he actually came back
and finished his PhD, which is pretty unusual. [INAUDIBLE]
OK, yeah. Yeah. PhD now, hypersonics. Yes, yes. Exactly.

So you raised the money from
Khosla, which is fantastic. And I'm impressed that you
got done in six months.

If we'd known each other, then
he asked my advice, I'd said, you need to give yourself
at least a year to try. Hey, we like to move fast.

Yeah, so I think
that's fantastic. You started the
company in Atlanta. That's right.

Talk about why you started
in Atlanta, and what's it like building a company in
a nontraditional environment

like that. Yeah. So I'll get to the good things,
but why did we build it there?

Well, we didn't have
any money to move. So we were like, well,
we're doing it here. But a number of things
that we found of--

there are a lot of people who
want to work on the hardest problems with the best people.

And in aerospace, most of
those problems in people are in Los Angeles. There's other places, obviously,
like San Francisco, Seattle,

a few others. But all West Coast. People move out here in droves
because they want to do that.

They want to work on the hardest
problems with the best people. So we had a hunch of like, well,
we have a really hard problem.

And if we can hold together
a set of good people, likely, we can attract
other good people who maybe actually do want
to live on the East Coast

because their family is closer,
or the cost of living is better. You can live a very
different lifestyle

than you live out here. And that ended up
being reasonably true.

I mean, we've been
able to, I'll say, repatriate a lot of folks who
really only moved out to LA

because that's where SpaceX was. So given an opportunity to get
in the early days of a company

working on a technical
problem and a business problem just as hard as what SpaceX is
doing was really attractive.

So we continued to build there. We've got a solid 110,000 square
foot manufacturing facility.

But also, over time, we've
expanded our footprint. So we have people in LA.

We've got a shop there. That footprint is going
to continue to expand over the coming years. And the test facility down in
Florida and the presence in DC.

So fundamentally,
as much as I want us to be a hardware
company in one building, on one floor, in one
room, where you really

get all of the awesome
collaboration that really creates great products,
the reality of the world

is that that isn't the case. So you better be good
at building a company over multiple places. So I think we'll continue
to grow in Atlanta.

I think our LA presence is
going to grow significantly. I wouldn't be surprised
if, in a couple of years, LA was as big or
bigger than Atlanta.

But, yeah, it's a great spot. So tell the group
a little bit now about the technical
architecture.

What's your approach to
what you're building, and what's the differentiator
or the secret sauce? Sure, sure.

So hypersonic airplane. What do you need to build
a hypersonic airplane? A couple core things
that are hard. The first thing is
an engine, an engine

where you can take off from the
ground and then cruise at Mach 5 for an extended period
of time, come back, land,

and do it again. And the reason you need that
type of architecture is-- well, it's one
core thing, but it

applies in both the
military applications and the civilian applications. You need to be able to integrate
with existing systems, existing

infrastructure. It's hard enough to
build a new airplane. If you have to
build a new airplane

and whatever the
hydrogen equivalent of charging infrastructure
is, or methane, or whatever in all these
places across the world,

and if the customer that you're
selling your airplanes to uses Jet A or kerosene
as their fuel,

you better use that
because you're not going to create a new airplane
and revolutionize the whole fuel

usage of the DOD. Don't try to solve
two hard problems. So that drove us
to an architecture

that was airbreathing
all the way through, a gas turbine engine for
low-speed operations.

And then we chose a ramjet
for high-speed operations. The reason for that is
because it was actually

driven by the commercial
side of the business. So we picked Mach 5
as the speed that we wanted to fly because, from
a commercial perspective,

literally, the planet
Earth is not large enough to need to go any faster. When you have a constraint
on acceleration,

how fast you can
accelerate, actually, if you go much
faster than Mach 5,

then you're just
accelerating the whole time and not cruising at all. So if the planet were bigger
like Jupiter or something,

that'd be cool to go faster. But rockets are a
little bit different. But we'll-- Give people some sense. At Mach 5, you're going
New York to London in--

90 minutes. 90 minutes. Yeah. OK. And a little under three
hours across the Pacific. Yeah. So it's fast.

Yeah, your movie
selection is pretty small.

By the way, some of
us are old enough to remember the
Concorde, which was-- what was the Concorde?
Mach 2. Mach 2. So this was a jet that-- I forget.

Was it the French
airline who operated it? British Airways and Air France. British Airways. Air France, yeah, operated it.

And you could go to
New York to Paris much faster than you can today.

But it had a fire, and people
got scared, and it got cut. It died of old age.

Died of old age. I mean, it flew for 30 years,
and it didn't have on accident. For those of us who
live on airplanes, we wish we could get
everywhere a little faster.
We're trying. We're trying. All right. So sorry to interrupt. Yeah, propulsion, core thing.

Make sure you can
get up to Mach 5. And then an efficient propulsion
system to cruise at that spot.

So ramjet was what
we chose for that. And we came up with a pretty
simple, straightforward way of putting those two
engines together, keeping

the cross-sectional
area very small. So it keeps the drag small
and the amount of thrust that you need small.

And we've been building
multiple iterations of that over the years. We've built five or
six at this point.

We've proven out the
whole architecture from not moving on the ground,
so far, up to about Mach 4. We've also demonstrated
the ability

to switch between the
two modes of operation, so ramjet and turbojet. We proved that out
in a wind tunnel.

And now, the next step is
to go do this in the air. And what's your
